# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is a Julia function that solves the problem:

```julia
using DataFrames, CategoricalArrays

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df[:audi_a4_type] = false
    filter!(r -> r.manufacturer == "audi" && (r.model == "a4" || r.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    df[:audi_a4_type] .= true
    return df
end
```
This function first initializes a new column `audi_a4_type` with all values set to false. It then filters the DataFrame such that only rows where manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro" remain. Finally, it sets the value of `audi_a4_type` for these rows to true.

You can use this function on your provided DataFrame as follows:

```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
df_cars = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
After running this code, `df_cars` will only contain rows where manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". The new column `audi_a4_type` will be true for these rows and false otherwise.
